Gen. William G. Webster, left, speaking with Lt. Gen. Anan |nickname= |allegiance={{flag|Egypt}} |branch= [[Egyptian Air Defense Command|Air Defense Forces]] |serviceyears= [[1967]] - |rank= [[File:EgyptianArmyInsignia-LieutenantGeneral.svg|25px]] [[Lieutenant General]] |commands= Battalion Commander (1981 - 1990)

[[Yom Kippur War]] |awards= Merit Of distinguished service
Medal of Long Service and Good Example |laterwork= }} General '''Sami Hafez Anan''' or '''Enan''' ({{lang-ar|Ø³Ø§ÙÙ Ø­Ø§ÙØ¸ Ø¹ÙØ§Ù}}, {{IPA-arz|ËsÃ¦Ëmi ËÄ§ÉËfezË¤ ÊÃ¦ËnÃ¦Ën, -ÊeËnÃ¦Ën|IPA}}; born 1948) is the [[Chief of Staff]] of the [[Egyptian Armed Forces]]. From 1990 to 1992 he was the Egyptain [[Defence AttachÃ©]] to Morocco. More recently he served as the Commander of the [[Egyptian Air Defence Forces]] from 2001 to 2005. He serves as Deputy Chairman of the [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]]. ==2011 events== When the [[2011 Egyptian Revolution]] began in January 2011, Anan was in [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]] "for a week of meetings with senior American officers".[http://www.voanews.com/english/news/usa/US-Egypt-Military-Relationship-Might-Impact-Crisis-114979569.html US-Egypt Military Relationship Might Impact Crisis], ''[[Voice of America]]'', 31 January 2011 Cutting his visit short, he returned to [[Egypt]] on 28 January. As the commander of an army of 468,000 troops, he was considered likely to play a crucial role in the political uncertainty surrounding the protests.[http://www.thenews.com.pk/TodaysPrintDetail.aspx?ID=3652&Cat=13&dt=1/30/2011 Lt-Gen Sami Anan will have the final say], ''[[The News International]]'', January 30, 2011 On 1 February 2011, the UK's [[Channel 4 News]] reported that the [[United States]] was pressing for Anan to play a role in coordinating interim arrangements for government in [[Egypt]] after [[Hosni Mubarak]].[[Jonathan Rugman]], ''Channel 4 News'', 1 February 2011 As the protests built momentum into their second week, there was considerable speculation whether Enan, on one hand, was "'too close to Mubarak to stay,' [per ...] [[Gawdat Bahgat]], a professor at [[National Defense University]] in Washington who has worked extensively with Egyptian officers attending the school," or, on the other, "a trusted partner. Retired Army Lt. Gen. [[R. Steven Whitcomb]], who oversaw joint exercises with the Egyptian military while stationed in the Middle East, invited Enan and his wife to his home at [[Fort McPherson]] in Atlanta for a private dinner in 2007. According to Whitcomb, Enan complained about the effect that budget cuts were having on the military as the Mubarak administration dealt with political and economic problems."Whitlock, Craig and Greg Jaffe, [http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/04/AR2011020407140_2.html "Where Egypt military's loyalties lie remains unclear"], ''Washington Post'', February 4, 2011. Second Web page. Retrieved 2011-02-06. The [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]] is the body of 18 senior military men, including Anan, to which the power to govern was handed by departing President Mubarak on February 11, 2011. Only [[Hussein Tantawi]] ranked ahead of Anan on the armed forces website and in the Council at that time, according to [[Al Jazeera]].[http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/111640/20110211/egypt-high-military-council-egypt-supreme-council-of-armed-forces.htm#ixzz1FHFcE9Bk "Who is in Egypt's High Military Council?"], ''International Business Times'', February 11, 2011 12:50 PM EST. Retrieved 2011-02-28. Assessing U.S. views of Enan thereafter, particularly by way of the [[Wikileaks#Diplomatic cables release|Wikileaks]] releases, ''The Guardian'' newspaper saw Enan "as more amenable to personal ties" than the older, change-resistant and standoffish Tantawi. Also, the story said, the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] "has described [Enan] as incorruptible and as one of its cleric[s] put it: 'He can be the future man of Egypt â¦ I think he will be acceptable.'" As the newspaper saw it, this gave the "[[Egypt#Rebublic|Soviet]]-trained" general an unusual span of support in the post-Mubarak government.Borger, Julian and James Ball, [http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/14/wikileaks-cables-egyptian-military-head "WikiLeaks cables: Egyptian military head is 'old and resistant to change'"], ''The Guardian'', 14 February 2011 10.41 GMT. Retrieved 2011-02-28. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.mmc.gov.eg/Commanders/chos/default.htm Chief of Staff] at the [[Egyptian Armed Forces]] *{{Aljazeeratopic|people/sami-hafez-anan}} *[http://www.silobreaker.com/biography-for-sami-anan-5_2260392001088258270_4 Biography] at silobreaker.com {{s-start}} {{s-mil}} {{s-bef|before=[[Mohammed Elshahat]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Commander of the [[Egyptian Air Defence Forces]]|years=2001 - 2005}} {{s-aft|after=[[Abd El Aziz Seif-Eldeen]]}} {{s-end}} {{Persondata | NAME = Anan, Sami | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[Chief of Staff]] of the [[Egyptian Armed Forces]] | DATE OF BIRTH = February 2, 1948 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Anan, Sami}} [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Egyptian generals]] [[Category:Members of the Supreme Council of Armed Forces]] [[ar:Ø³Ø§ÙÙ Ø­Ø§ÙØ¸ Ø¹ÙØ§Ù]] [[de:Sami Hafez Enan]] [[fa:Ø³Ø§ÙÛ Ø¹ÙØ§Ù]] [[he:×¡×× ×¢× ××]] [[nl:Sami Hafez Enan]] [[sl:Sami Hafez Anan]]
